awd_titl_txt: Analytic Number Theory on Higher Rank Groups
awd_abstract_narration:
This project concerns research in the theory of numbers, in particular questions related to the distribution of prime numbers. One of the most fundamental open questions in modern number theory is the Riemann hypothesis, which connects the distribution of prime numbers with the distribution of complex zeros of the generating zeta function, the Riemann zeta function. The Riemann hypothesis asserts that the non-integer zeros lie on a line. The Riemann Zeta function is an example of an L-function. This is a project to study zeroes of general L-functions. 

In more detail, a Siegel zero is a type of potential counterexample to the (generalized) Riemann hypothesis on the zeros of Dirichlet L-functions connected to the study of the distribution of primes in arithmetic progressions. In the main part of this project, based on Sarnak's method, a novel technique will be used to derive the standard zero-free regions for general L-functions. This new technique combines the use of Maass-Selberg relations on higher rank groups which is expected to remove the technical sieve arguments in Sarnak's work. The new technique will also shed light on the classical Siegel zero problem as mentioned above. Other projects include the study of equidistribution of Maass forms on higher rank groups and spectral identities for L-functions. These will provide new bridges between analytic number theory, representation theory and ergodic theory.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:  

This proposal concerns research in the theory of numbers, in particular questions related to the distribution of prime numbers. One of the most fundamental open problems in modern mathematics is the Riemann hypothesis, which connects the distribution of prime numbers with the distribution of complex zeros of the generating zeta function, the Riemann zeta function. The hypothesis asserts that all the nontrivial zeros lie on a central line. In mathematics, more specifically in the field of analytic number theory, a Siegel zero, is a type of potential counterexample to the generalized Riemann hypothesis, on the zeros of Dirichlet L-function associated to quadratic number fields.

In this proposal, based on Sarnak?s method, a novel technique has been put forward to derive the standard zero free regions for general L−functions. This new technique combines the use of Maass-Selberg relations on higher rank groups which is expected to remove the technical sieve arguments in Sarnak?s work. Hopefully this new technique sheds light on the classical Siegel zero problem as mentioned above.

 

Broader Impacts:

 In 2014, the PI gave three lectures at Columbia Univ. and invited talks at CUNY, Rutgers and Sarnak?s birthday conference at Princeton Univ. In 2015, the PI gave an invited talk at Yale Univ. In 2018, the PI gave an invited talk on Goldfeld?s birthday conference in China. All these talks are related to the project. Many of the projects listed in the proposal naturally suggest sub-projects based on understanding particular examples. These could easily be turned into thesis topics for graduate students as their PhD thesis problems. The principal investigator has been working with her PhD students who are interested in the subject. To cultivate interests among graduate students, the principal investigator has taught graduate topic courses based on the research.

 

Results produced:

  1. A preprint on deriving the standard zero free region of the Riemann zeta function using the GL(3) Maass-Selberg relation was written;
  2. Fourier expansions at different cusps of L-functions on GL(3) congruence subgroups were derived and the truncated Eisenstein series for the GL(3) congruence subgroups were constructed;
  3. A novel way in deriving the GL(3) Maass-Selberg relation was discovered.
